revision.comment: Removing {{[[Template:Blacklisted-links|Blacklisted-links]]}}. No blacklisted links were found. ([[en:WP:PEACHY|Peachy 2.0 (alpha 8)]])
revision.text:
The '''Chinese magic mirror''' is an ancient art that can be traced back to the Chinese [[Han dynasty]] (206 BC – 24 AD).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mak |first=Se-yuen |author2=Yip, Din-yan |title=Secrets of the Chinese magic mirror replica |journal=Physics Education |year=2001 |volume=36 |issue=2 |pages=102–107 |doi=10.1088/0031-9120/36/2/302 |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/0031-9120/36/2/302}}</ref> The mirrors were made out of solid [[bronze]]. The front is a shiny polished surface and could be used as a mirror, while the back has a design cast in the bronze.<ref name=unesco-courrier>{{cite journal |journal=The Courier |date=October 1988 |pages=16–17 |url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0008/000817/081712eo.pdf |title=Magic Mirrors |accessdate=23 August 2011 |publisher=Unesco |issn=0041-5278}}</ref> When bright sunlight or other bright light reflects onto the mirror, the mirror seems to become [[transparency and translucency|transparent]]. If that light is reflected from the mirror towards a wall, the pattern on the back of the mirror is then projected onto the wall.<ref name=unesco-courrier/>
In about 800 AD, during the [[Tang dynasty]] (618–907), a book entitled ''Record of Ancient Mirrors'' described the method of crafting solid [[bronze mirror]]s with decorations, written characters, or patterns on the reverse side that could cast these in a reflection on a nearby surface as light struck the front, polished side of the mirror; due to this seemingly [[Transparency (optics)|transparent effect]], they were called "light-penetration mirrors" by the Chinese.<ref name=unesco-courrier/><ref name="temple">Temple, Robert (1986). ''The Genius of China: 3,000 Years of Science, Discovery, and Invention.'' New York: Simon and Schuster, Inc. p. 66-67 {{ISBN|0-671-62028-2}}.</ref> This Tang era book was lost over the centuries, but magic mirrors were described in the ''[[Dream Pool Essays]]'' by [[Shen Kuo]] (1031–1095), who owned three of them as a family [[heirloom]].<ref name=unesco-courrier/><ref name="temple"/> Perplexed as to how solid metal could be transparent, Shen guessed that some sort of [[quench]]ing technique was used to produce tiny wrinkles on the face of the mirror too small to be observed by the eye.<ref name=unesco-courrier/><ref name="temple"/> Although his explanation of different cooling rates was incorrect, he was right to suggest the surface contained minute variations which the naked eye could not detect; these mirrors also had no transparent quality at all, as discovered by [[William Henry Bragg|William Bragg]] in 1932 (after an entire century of them confounding Western scientists).<ref name=unesco-courrier/><ref name="temple"/>
Robert Temple describes their construction: "The basic mirror shape, with the design on the back, was cast flat, and the convexity of the surface produced afterwards by elaborate scraping and scratching. The surface was then polished to become shiny. The stresses set up by these processes caused the thinner parts of the surface to bulge outwards and become more convex than the thicker portions. Finally, a [[Mercury (element)|mercury]] amalgam was laid over the surface; this created further stresses and preferential buckling. The result was that imperfections of the mirror surface matched the patterns on the back, although they were too minute to be seen by the eye. But when the mirror reflected bright sunlight against a wall, with the resultant magnification of the whole image, the effect was to reproduce the patterns as if they were passing through the solid bronze by way of light beams."<ref name="unesco-courrier" /><ref name="temple" />
[[Michael Berry (physicist)|Michael Berry]] has written a paper describing the optics and giving some photos.<ref>[http://michaelberryphysics.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/berry383.pdf "Oriental magic mirrors and the Laplacian image"] by Michael Berry, Eur. J. Phys. 27 (2006) 109–118, DOI: [https://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0143-0807/27/1/012 10.1088/0143-0807/27/1/012]</ref>
==See also== *[[TLV mirror]] *[[Bronze mirror]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2018}} {{multiple issues| {{cleanup|date=September 2011}} {{More citations needed|date=September 2011}} }}
'''Cholamandal Artists' Village''', established in 1966, is the largest artists' commune in India. Its artists are credited for the Madras Movement of Art (1950s–1980s), which brought [[modernism]] to art in [[South India]]. Their work is widely recognized as some of the best art produced in postwar India and is shown regularly in galleries across the country. Several Cholamandal artists have also shown in Europe, the United States and South America.<ref>{{Cite web|title=In India, Pioneers of Modernism Savor Their Success |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/29/arts/arts-abroad-in-india-pioneers-of-modernism-savor-their-success.html?pagewanted=all |date=29 January 1998 |work=[[The New York Times]] |author=[[Stephen Kinzer]]}}</ref>
In the village [[Injambakkam]], 9 km from [[Chennai]], [[India]], it has over 20 resident painters and sculptors, who live as a community and pool their skills. They run the Artists Handicrafts Association, a cooperative which manages the village and sale of works through the permanent exhibition at the complex, which includes paintings, sketches, terra-cotta/stone/metal sculptures, batiks and handicrafts etc., making the village a self-supporting entity.<ref>[http://www.india9.com/i9show/Cholamandal-Artists%27-Village-25859.htm Cholamandal Artists' Village]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Celebrate the oeuvre|url=http://www.hindu.com/businessline/2000/10/02/stories/100244m2.htm|date=2 October 2000|publisher=[[Business Line]]|page=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Artists have a gallery of their own |date=3 February 2009 |url=http://www.expressbuzz.com/edition/story.aspx?Title=Artists+have+a+gallery+of+their+own&artid=4FU2zKzGNkY=&SectionID=lifojHIWDUU=&MainSectionID=wIcBMLGbUJI=&SectionName=rSY%7C6QYp3kQ=&SEO= |work=ExpressBuzz |accessdate=20 February 2009}}</ref>
The community was founded by [[K. C. S. Paniker]], the principal of the [[Government College of Fine Arts, Chennai|Madras School of Arts]], along with his students and a few artists associated with the college. It used the `art-meets-craft' approach where artists made handicrafts for a living as they pursued their art. By the 1970s, the village became self-sufficient and grew into one of the most important meeting places for international artists in India. Today, it is one of the few artist-driven movements in India. Four decades on, it is one of the few artists' colonies in the world to survive successfully and its foundation remains one of the "10 biggest art moments" in India.<ref name=ec/><ref>{{Cite web|title=10 biggest art moments |url= http://indiatoday.intoday.in/index.php?issueid=116&id=22988&option=com_content&task=view&sectionid=25|date=19 December 2008 |publisher=[[India Today]] |page=}}</ref>
==History== Most of the original founding creative artists, painters and sculptors were students and artists associated with the [[Government School of Arts and Crafts, Chennai]] (Madras School of Arts), where [K.C.S. Paniker], noted metaphysical and abstract painter, was principal 1957 to 1967. These artists desired to form a congenial space for practising their art; 38 of them got together and formed the 'Artists Handicrafts Association' (AHA) in 1963 initially to sell the works of artists.
Gradually, the artists started working together, producing handicrafts in their spare time. They were among the first in the country to produce [[batik]] fabric; proceeds of their first batik exhibition went into buying the {{convert|8.5|acre|m2}} of land in 1966, which was to make up the village.<ref name=art/> By now K.C.S. Paniker had retired and founded the artists commune in April 1966.
It was named after the [[Chola dynasty]], which is known to have encouraged arts and ruled the region, 9-13th century AD — called ''Cholamandalam'' in [[Tamil language|Tamil]], which literally translated as ''the realm of the [[Chola]]s''. Chola also lends its name to the [[Coromandel Coast]] of [[Bay of Bengal]], which is a short walk from the village.<ref name=ab>[http://www.cholamandalartistsvillage.org/aboutus.html About us]</ref> Paniker was "worried that his students might deviate from art due to financial compulsions".<ref>{{Cite web|title=Tantric geometry: Velu Viswanadhan|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/story_print.php?storyId=30155 |date=5 May 2007 |publisher=[[Indian Express]] |page=|quote="“Panicker was worried that his students might deviate from art due to financial compulsions. 'Cholamandalam gave them the security,' says Viswanadhan."}}</ref>
In the same year six artists moved into live and work on their own land. In the 60s, while they could hardly sell their paintings, avant garde wood and leather work, batik, ceramics and metal craft, they found a good market. This sustained them, while the local buyers were familiarized to modernism, which their art represented.
Electricity was provided in 1968 and till 1972 the mud road ended at [[Muttukadu boat house|Muttukadu]]. The village was on a lonely, bumpy road, now known as the [[East Coast Road]] highway to [[Mahabalipuram]], from [[Adyar (Tamil Nadu)|Adyar]]. Chennai was further away, though today, it is right at its door steps, and the road is busy with traffic and shops and commercial establishments. Over the years, built their houses, studios, exhibition gallery, theatre, workshop and kitchen, which they jointly owned along with all the infrastructure of the village.
It nurtured artists such as [[J. Sultan Ali]], [[K.M. Gopal|Dr. K.M. Gopal]]<ref>{{cite book | last1 = K.M | first1 = Gopal | first2 = Selin | last2 = George | first3 =Meenatchi | last3 = Gopal | title = [[Tantric Sculptor Dr. K.M. Gopal]] | location = London | publisher = [[Kalaimaiyam UK]] | page = 12 | date = November 2017 | isbn = 978-1-912506-00-2 }}</ref> [[S. Kanniappan]], K. Ramanujam, M. Reddeppa Naidu, S. P. Jayakar, K.R. Harie, P.S. Nandan, D. Venkatapathy, Haridasan, S. Nanda Gopal, S.G. Vasudev, K. Jayapala Panicker, Gopinath, Senathipathy, M.V. Devan and Richard Jesudas. Soon they formed a cooperative to look after the village and built a gallery, which displayed and sold their works; 20% of their sales went to the ‘Cholamandal Artists Handicrafts Association’, which used the funds for village upkeep. In time the cooperative became self-sufficient and held exhibitions of their work in major cities of India.<ref>{{Cite book|title=India: Country Guides, Lonely Planet |last= Singh|first=Sarina|authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2007|publisher=[[Lonely Planet]]|location= |isbn=1-74104-308-5|page=1044 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T7ZHUhSEleYC&pg=PA1044&dq=%22Cholamandal+Artists+Village%22#v=onepage&q=%22Cholamandal%20Artists%20Village%22&f=false |ref= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Cholamandal collection |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/life/2009/02/27/stories/2009022750120400.htm |date=27 February 2009 |publisher=[[Business Line]] |page=}}</ref>
K.C.S. Paniker died in 1977. By this time the module had proven sustainable.<ref name=ab/> Over the years, work done by the artists at the village, initiated a period in south Indian art called the 'Madras Movement', which brought modernism to [[south India]]n art. The Progressive Painters’ Association (P.P.A.), one of the oldest art associations in India founded by Paniker in Chennai in 1944; it was inactive for many year after Paniker's death. The association was revived in 2006 and a new committee formed. It is now being carried forward by artists at the village<ref>{{Cite web|title=For art’s sake |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2009/02/12/stories/2009021251330400.htm |date= 12 February 2009|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|page=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Brush with peace- Cholamandal: an Artists Village (OUP), edited by Josef James |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mag/2004/07/18/stories/2004071800020100.htm |date=18 July 2004 |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |page=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Progressive strokes |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2006/03/04/stories/2006030401800500.htm|date=4 March 2006 |newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|page=}}</ref> and an annually elected general council of members administers Cholamandal. The village continues to produce artists of great talent such as [[S. Ravi Shankar]], A. Selveraj and [https://web.archive.org/web/20100505044114/http://www.thenoblesage.com/page544.html Shailesh B.O.] amongst many others.
==Cholamandal Centre for Contemporary Art== During his last days Paniker had offered his oeuvre to the Madras government on the condition that a separate gallery be created for his work. When no response came from the government, the Trivandrum Art Gallery took up the offer and now houses an important collection of Paniker's work. The artists at the village wanted a place to display the work of the Madras Movement, thus idea of the art museum took place.<ref name=ec/>
The artists raised money from the private sector to fund a museum in the village, which would house a permanent collection of artworks representative of the Madras Movement.<ref name=art>{{Cite web|title=Arts and ideas|url=http://www.hindu.com/businessline/2000/12/04/stories/100444a3.htm|date=4 December 2000 |publisher=[[Business Line]] |page=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Master takes |url=http://www.tehelka.com/story_main42.asp?filename=hub080809mastertakes.asp |date=8 August 2009 |publisher=[[Tehelka]] |page=}}</ref> While the initial design was made by a visiting Dutch couple, the design for the art centre was made by architects [[Sheila Sri Prakash]] of [[Shilpa Architects]] and M. V. Devan. As the project gathered momentum help came in from artists and corporates alike.
After three and half years of construction the building was finished — thus started a long search for works that exemplified the Madras Movement, which flourished between the early 50s and the 80s. Eventually about 60 per cent of the works were donated by senior artists and the rest were given on extended loan by art collectors around the country.<ref>{{Cite web|title= Another first for Indian art |url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2008/06/03/stories/2008060350110100.htm |date=3 June 2008 |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |page=}}</ref>
The Cholamandal Centre for Contemporary Art opened on 1 February 2009. It has a 'Museum of the Madras Movement', which display works of prominent artists of the movement (apart from that of Paniker) including J. Sultan Ali, [[K.M. Gopal|Dr. K.M. Gopal]] M. Senathipathi, Late [[A.P. Santhanaraj]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20090518010148/http://www.thenoblesage.com/page278.html P.S. Nandhan], [[S.G. Vasudev]], K.V. Haridasan, Thotta Tharani, Sculptor S. Nandagopal. The centre has two commercial galleries, 'Labernum' and 'Indigo', that can be rented free of commission charge, an art book store, and a craft shop. It is surrounded by tree-shaded sands which sport an international sculpture garden, displaying sculptures made by visiting artists from across India and the world through the decades.<ref name=ec>{{Cite web|title= Eclectic mix of styles |url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/thscrip/print.pl?file=2003011300100200.htm&date=2003/01/13/&prd=mp& |date= 13 January 2003|newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |page=}}</ref>
==Facilities== Today, the village houses art galleries, museums, and an open-air theatre for dance and theatre performances.<ref>{{Cite book|author=Pippa de Bruyn |title=Frommer's India |url=https://books.google.com/?id=IzF1NZwot2cC&pg=PA233&lpg=PA233&dq=%22Cholamandalam+Artists+Village%22 |page=223 |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |year=2006 |isbn=0-7645-9899-6 }}</ref> The original Artists Handicrafts Association is still in charge of the colony, and Paniker's son, sculptor S. Nandagopal, is the secretary of the village. Out of the original 40 artists, many are no more, and some have moved out, only 21 remain today. Cholamandal does not accept new members, though it has at least a dozen artists living or working there at any time, plus many artists-in-residence are at work.<ref name=art/>
The village is open daily from 10am to 5pm. It is 10-minute walking distance from the Golden Beach. Local transport is easily available, and the Chennai International Airport is the nearest airport.
==Further reading== * ''Artists of Cholamandal Artists' Village Madras'', Artists' Handicrafts Association of Cholamandal Artists Village. Published s.n., 1979. * ''Two decades of Cholamandal Artists' Village'', Cholamandal Artists' Village (Adyār, India). Publisher s.n., 1987. * Josef James, 2004, ''Cholamandal: An Artist's Village'', Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-566988-6}}.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portalbar|Chennai|Culture|Arts|Art}}

{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | italic title = (see above) | name = Decoded | image = Jay Z Decoded Hardcover Cover.jpg | image_size = | caption = The book's cover | alt = | author = [[Jay-Z]] | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = [[Rodrigo Corral]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = Autobiography | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | published = November 16th, 2010 (Hardcover), November 1st, 2011 (Softcover) | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] and [[Softcover]]) | pages = 336 (Hardcover) 352 (Softcover) | awards = | isbn = 1400068924 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | wikisource = | exclude_cover = }} '''''Decoded''''' is the autobiography and memoir of rapper [[Jay-Z]], published by [[Random House]] and released November 16, 2010 on Hardcover and November 1, 2011 on Paperback.<ref name="amazon">{{cite web|title=Decoded|url=https://www.amazon.com/Decoded-Jay-Z/dp/1400068924/ref=br_lf_m_1000623831_1_6_ttl?ie=UTF8&s=books&pf_rd_p=1278243542&pf_rd_s=center-2&pf_rd_t=1401&pf_rd_i=1000623831&pf_rd_m=ATVPDKIKX0DER&pf_rd_r=0F5A1QS83G9RD5VSFD8S|publisher=Amazon}}</ref> The book combines lyrics, their explanations, anecdotes, reflections, and autobiographical information. [[Jay-Z]] explains the three reasons why he wanted to write the book being a case for hip-hop lyrics as poetry, to tell a generational story turned into powerful experiences and revolved as a story everyone can relate to.<ref name="Jay2010">{{cite book|last=Jay-Z|title=Decoded|year=2010|publisher=Random House|location=New York, New York|isbn=9781400068920|pages=235}}</ref>
==Summary==
===Narrative=== The book follows very rough chronological order, while switching from current stories to his story of growing up in the [[Marcy Projects]]. The autobiographical portion focuses on growing up in poverty which led to him to drug dealing during the [[crack epidemic]], fights, and a need to share the hustlers story during the beginnings in rap. His reflections on those harsh times shaped who he is and how artists are shaped by such experiences.
===Celebrity life=== [[Jay-Z]] explains the stresses of the rap industry and the celebrity life, while also trying to put it in perspective. He illustrates this point by explaining that when he and [[Puff Daddy]] were being charged with assault there were hundreds of cameras outside the courthouse of [[Puff Daddy]]'s trial and the courthouse where the perpetrator of the [[World Trade Center bombing]] was being tried was empty.
===Opinions and reflections=== Along with the narrative, there is also a substantial portion of the book dedicated to [[Jay-Z]]'s opinions and reflections, which are often illustrated with stories. [[Jay-Z]] expounds on his relationship with [[Barack Obama]] and his involvement in politics, as well as his thoughts on the [[Hurricane Katrina]]. [[Jay-Z]] reflects on his life and especially his beginnings. He explains that he still considers himself a hustler, despite being a corporate billionaire now as founder of [[Roc-A-Fella Records]]. He continues and describes the comparisons between drug dealing, rapping, and boxing and how his life in the streets has molded who he is and no matter how he lives now, he still acknowledges his roots.
===Lyrics=== The book contains lyrics to thirty-six songs with some songs having only part of the song.<ref name="etonline">{{cite web|title=Jay-Z to 'Decode' Lyrics in New Book |url=http://www.etonline.com/music/101041_Jay_Z_to_Decode_Lyrics_in_New_Book/index.html |publisher=Entertainment Tonight |accessdate=25 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019174402/http://www.etonline.com/music/101041_Jay_Z_to_Decode_Lyrics_in_New_Book/index.html |archivedate=19 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> Along with the lyrics, there are annotations and footnotes that Jay-Z writes to explain the lyrics to the reader. The explanations range from just explaining what a "brick" is to in depth analysis and explanation of lines that underscore the points that [[Jay-Z]] makes in his writing.
==Critical response== Most of the criticism is that the book is not personal enough and does not provide enough detail of [[Jay-Z]]'s life. Simon Vozick-Levinson writes in [[Entertainment Weekly]] ""Despite the career he has made out of rapping in the first person, Jay-Z is known for prizing privacy. His new book 'Decoded' may not erase that reputation." Although Vozick Levinson expands and reveals "it is nonetheless [[Shawn Carter]]'s most honest airing of the experiences he drew on to create the mythic figure of [[Jay-Z]]," while giving the book a grade of A-.<ref name="ew">{{cite web|last=Vozick-Levinson|first=Simon|title=Book Review: Decoded, Jay-Z|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20440841,00.html|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref> Adam Bradley of [[Barnes & Noble]] criticizes the structure of the book because it is not organized by chronological order, but by subject as well as criticizes its lack of depth in some areas by explaining "At times, these subject-driven sections leave one dissatisfied with the level of revelation and reflection, such as in his cursory treatment of race relations.<ref name="bnreview.barnesandnoble">{{cite web|last=Bradley|first=Adam|title=Life of an Artist: Decoded, Jay-Z|url=http://bnreview.barnesandnoble.com/t5/Reviews-Essays/Decoded/ba-p/3619|publisher=Barnes & Noble|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref>"
==Plagiarism claims== On June 13, 2012 a lawsuit was filed in the [[United States District Court for the Central District of California]] accusing [[Jay-Z]] and coauthor [[Dream Hampton]] of copyright infringement and invasion of privacy for ''Decoded.'' The lawsuit, filed by Patrick White also names [[Random House]], the company that published ''Decoded.'' White alleges "In 2009, my personal computer was compromised, resulting in my personal work to be used in [[Jay-Z]]'s book 'Decoded' which was released in 2010.<ref name="xxlmag">{{cite web|last=Narunsky|first=Kim|title=Jay-Z Sued For Copyright Infringement Over Decoded Book|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2012/06/jay-z-sued-for-copyright-infringement-over-decoded-book/|publisher=XXL Magazine|accessdate=24 September 2012}}</ref>" White is claiming that he was working on a book on his personal computer when it was compromised and when reading ''Decoded'', he noticed a resemblance in "expressions/color/phrases, which correlates to my work.<ref name="xxlmag" />" In the handwritten lawsuit, White alleges that he sought out [[Jay-Z]] and [[Dream Hampton]], but they were unresponsive to his contact.<ref name="allhiphop">{{cite web|last=Watkins|first=Greg|title=EXCLUSIVE: Jay-Z Sued Over Book "Decoded"|url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/06/18/exclusive-jay-z-sued-over-book-decoded/|publisher=All Hip-Hop.com|accessdate=September 24, 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

[[Category:2010 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Jay-Z]] [[Category:American autobiographies]] [[Category:Music autobiographies]] [[Category:Books involved in plagiarism controversies]] [[Category:Books with cover art by Rodrigo Corral]]

In the design of [[user interface|human-machine user interfaces]] (HMIs or UIs), the '''Design Eye Position (DEP)''' is the position from which the user is intended to view the [[workstation]] for an optimal view of the visual interface. The Design Eye Position represents the ideal but notional location of the operator's view and is usually expressed as a monocular point midway between the pupils of the average user. The DEP may also allow for a standardisation of monocular and binocular "Field of View" and may be integrated into the [[CAD/CAM]] design system used to define the workstation build.<ref>[http://cockpiteval.home.att.net/MilStd1333.htm US Military Standard 1333A, Aircrew Station Geometry For Military Aircraft]</ref>
The DEP is particularly important in those operator workstations, such as the [[cockpit]] of a military fast jet, where an accurate reading of information and symbols on displays may be critical. When designing such user interfaces the DEP is used as the reference point for the location of items (e.g. displays or controls) within the interface.
== Military Aviation == With [[collimated]] displays, such of the cockpit [[Head Up Display]], the projected symbology is aligned very precisely with the outside world to allow for precise delivery of weapons and also for safe landing. Unless located at the Design Eye Position the pilot cannot see the symbology as it is effectively focussed at infinity. Similarly, Head Down Displays will usually be angled precisely towards the DEP so that all symbols may be equally visible to the pilot without parallax or other display distortion errors.
Pilots who are below or above the 50% percentile point for sitting height, i.e. not of average stature, may need to adjust the seat in order to attain the DEP, even if this means compromising their optimal reach envelope. This is why, for example, rudder pedals may need to be adjustable.

{{italic title}} [[File:Endless Night K83.jpg|thumb|right|275px|''Endless Night'', oil on canvas, 2.25 X 3 meters (7.5 X 10 feet), 1983]]
'''''Endless Night''''' is the title of a [[painting]] executed in 1983 by [[Nabil Kanso]] in [[Oil painting|oil paint]] on [[canvas]] measuring 2.25 X 3 meters (7.5 X 10 feet).<ref>''Nabil Kanso: Paintings 1974-94'', p.69, NEV Editions, Atlanta, 1996</ref> It is part of a group of interrelated paintings made by Kanso in response to the [[Lebanese Civil War]].<ref>Fox, Catherine, ''Artist Inspired by War-Torn Homeland,'' The Atlanta Journal – The Atlanta Constitution, p. 5 H, July 8, 1984, online [http://lebanonpainting.com/fox.html]</ref><ref>Rossi, I: ''Nabil Kanso Work'', Panorama, April 10, 1985, Maracaibo, article [http://lebanonwarpainting.com/panorama.html]</ref> The painting depicts the ravages war in a scene that “embodies recurrent themes of carnage, suffering and the disintegration of humanity."<ref>Fox, ''Artist Inspired by War,'' The Atlanta Journal, p.5H</ref>
The composition seems to divide the canvas in two zones that contrast one mass of helpless and tormented figures on the left and one group of complacent looking and rigidly poised figures on the upper right. The focal point appears to fall between the two contrasting sections toward the central horizontal line in the middle distance creating a variation of focus that moves from one side to another and spread the attention over the various areas.<ref>''Nabil Kanso: Paintings 1980-83'', Catalog, p. 19, Atlanta, 1983</ref> The swirls of somber tone emanating from the blaze of torched places in the background seem to reinforce the tense mood and sharpen the interplay of dark and light.<ref>Fuenmayor, Carlos, Space Cries, Time Cries, La Columna, pp.8-9, May 21, 1987, Maracaibo, article [http://lebanonwarpainting.com/fuenmayor.html]</ref> Critical opinion notes “A dark palette tending to brown is set afire by strongly contrasting hues. A lurid orange illuminates the ''Endless Night'', in which figures with masklike faces standing on a parapet stonily witness the suffering of people and animals below.”<ref>Fox, Catherine, ''The Political Show'', Atlanta Journal – Constitution, p. 3H, June 24, 1984, [http://lebanonwarpainting.com/ajc684.html]</ref>
==See also== *[[Lebanon (painting)|''Lebanon'' (painting)]] *''[[Lebanon Summer 1982]]'' *''[[The Vortices of Wrath (Lebanon 1977)]]''

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Catalog-Exhibition-LOSH-51-bw.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=200px | title=Exhibition of Leningrad artists. Leningrad, 1951. Catalog | artist= | year=1951 | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] | museum=[[Russian Museum|State Russian Museum]] }} '''Exhibition of Leningrad artists of 1951''' ({{lang-ru|Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года}}) became one of the notable event in Art live of Leningrad of the beginning of 1950s. The Exhibition took place in the [[Russian Museum|State Russian Museum]].
== History and organization == Exhibition was opened on November, 22, and worked up to December, 4, 1951. Organization and preparation of the annual Exhibition of Leningrad artists engaged specially formed Exhibition Committee which consisted of 26 the authoritative art-experts. It was published a Catalog of the exhibition.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года. Каталог''. Л., Лениздат, 1951.</ref> Exhibition displayed works of art of leading Leningraf's painters, sculptors, and graphics artists.
== Contributing artists == In the largest Department of Painting were exhibited art works of 126 authors. There were [[Piotr Alberti]], [[Vladislav Anisovich]], Vladimir Avlas, Nikolai Babasuk, [[Vsevolod Bazhenov]], [[Piotr Belousov]], [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], [[Lev Bogomolets]], [[Piotr Buchkin]], [[Boris Fogel]], [[Rudolf Frentz]], [[Nikolai Galakhov]], [[Ivan Godlevsky]], [[Vladimir Gorb]], [[Tatiana Kopnina]], [[Nikolai Kostrov]], [[Anna Kostrova]], [[Anatoli Levitin]], [[Alexander Lubimov]], Vladimir Malagys, [[Evsey Moiseenko]], [[Andrei Mylnikov]], [[Mikhail Natarevich]], [[Yuri Neprintsev]], [[Yaroslav Nikolaev]], [[Vladimir Ovchinnikov (painter)|Vladimir Ovchinnikov]], [[Sergei Ivanovich Osipov|Sergei Osipov]], [[Filaret Pakun]], [[Genrikh Pavlovsky]], [[Varlen Pen]], [[Stepan Privedentsev]], [[Alexander Pushnin]], [[Ivan Savenko]], [[Gleb Savinov]], [[Alexander Nikolayevich Samokhvalov|Alexander Samokhvalov]], [[Vladimir Seleznev]], [[Alexander Shmidt]], [[Nadezhda Shteinmiller]], [[Nikolai Timkov]], [[Leonid Tkachenko (artist)|Leonid Tkachenko]], [[Mikhail Tkachev]], [[Yuri Tulin]], [[Igor Veselkin]], [[Nina Veselova]], [[Rostislav Vovkushevsky]], [[Vecheslav Zagonek]], [[Elena Zhukova]], and others most prominent painters of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad School]].<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года. Каталог''. Л., Лениздат, 1951.</ref>
In the Department of Sculptures were exhibited art works of 49 sculptors. Department of graphics presented a creation of 69 artists.
== Contributed artworks == [[File:Russian museam.JPG|thumb|340px|[[Russian Museum|''State Russian Museum'']]]]
For the Exhibition were selected art works created in years of 1950-1951, also some earlier works. All they were exhibited in the first time. Some of them were subsequently found in the collections of leading Soviet Art museums, as well as domestic and foreign galleries and collectors. In exposition were presented all genres of contemporary painting: portrait, historical and genre painting, landscape and cityscape, still life.
'''Genre painting''' was presented of ''"Chess Players"'' by [[Piotr Alberti]], ''"A Peaceful sleep"'' by [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], ''"Fishing season"'' by [[Lev Bogomolets]], ''"Harvest"'' by [[Piotr Buchkin]], ''"in Murmansk Sea Port"'' by [[Boris Fogel]], ''"Harvester in the field"'' by [[Nikolai Kostrov]], ''"A Horse with a foal"'' by [[Anna Kostrova]], ''"Horserace"'' by [[Evsey Moiseenko]], ''"In Bashkiria"'' by [[Andrei Mylnikov]], ''"In the Morning"'' by [[Mikhail Natarevich]], ''"On the construction sites of Communism"'' by [[Genrikh Pavlovsky]], ''"Agitator among farmers"'' by [[Stepan Privedentsev]], ''"Along the shores of the Motherland"'' by [[Alexander Nikolayevich Samokhvalov|Alexander Samokhvalov]], ''"In Gidroturbinn workshop of the plant named after Stalin"'' by [[Nina Veselova]], [[Yuri Tulin]], [[Vecheslav Zagonek]], [[Alexander Pushnin]], ''"Meeting of the Scientific and Technical Council of the "Electrosyla" plant"'' by [[Leonid Tkachenko (artist)|Leonid Tkachenko]], ''"Harvesting"'' by [[Mikhail Tkachev]], and some others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года. Каталог''. Л., Лениздат, 1951.</ref>
'''Historical painting''' was presented of ''"Stalin and Voroshilov in the defense of Tsaritsyn"'' by Nikolai Babasuk, ''"We'll go the other way"'' by [[Piotr Belousov]], ''"Storming of the Winter Palace"'' by [[Rudolf Frentz]], ''"October, 20"'' by [[Ivan Godlevsky]], ''"Rest after the Battle. Vasily Terkin"'' by [[Yuri Neprintsev]], ''"On the tsar's penal servitude"'' by [[Yaroslav Nikolaev]], ''"In Gorki"'' by [[Vladimir Seleznev]], and some others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года. Каталог''. Л., Лениздат, 1951.</ref>
'''Portrait''' was presented of ''"Academician Mikhail Kostenko"'' by [[Mikhail Anikushin]], ''"Portrait of Strogov"'' by [[Vladislav Anisovich]], ''"Pigeon"'' by [[Olga Bogaevskaya]], ''"A Collective farm's shepherd"'' by [[Piotr Buchkin]], ''"Portrait of Ekaterina Podovinnikova"'' by [[Vladimir Gorb]], ''"Schoolgirl"'' and ''"Portrait of A. Karnovskaya"'' by [[Tatiana Kopnina]], ''"Portrait of F. Lysko"'' by [[Anatoli Levitin]], ''"Portrait of artist Piotr Buchkin"'' and ''"Portrait of artist Yuri Neprintsev"'' by [[Alexander Lubimov]], ''"Alexander Matrosov"'' by [[Gleb Savinov]], ''"Man's Portrait"'' by [[Igor Veselkin]], and some others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года. Каталог''. Л., Лениздат, 1951.</ref>
'''Landscape and Cityscape''' were presented of ''"The Beginning of Spring"'' by [[Vsevolod Bazhenov]], ''"Here will be the Kuibyshevskaya Hydroelectric Power Station"''<ref>''Галахов Н. Это Родина моя.'' СПб., Арт-Центр, 2009. С.14-15.</ref> by [[Nikolai Galakhov]], ''"Sheaves"'' by [[Nikolai Kostrov]], ''"Cloudy day in Bashkiria"'' by [[Andrei Mylnikov]], ''"Evening landscape"'' by [[Yaroslav Nikolaev]], ''"On the Volga River"'' by [[Vladimir Ovchinnikov (painter)|Vladimir Ovchinnikov]], ''"On the Volga River"'' by [[Sergei Ivanovich Osipov|Sergei Osipov]], ''"On the Lake"'' and ''"Grey Day"'' by [[Filaret Pakun]], ''"In Korea"'' by [[Varlen Pen]], ''"Soon the harvest"'' and ''"Lights of Kolkhoz HPS"'' by [[Nikolai Timkov]], ''"The Embankment of Griboedov Canal"'' by [[Alexander Shmidt]], ''"Cityscape of the Leningrad"'' by [[Nadezhda Shteinmiller]], ''"Evening in Mountains"'' and ''"A Winter in Mountains"'' by [[Rostislav Vovkushevsky]], ''"Academicheskaya Dacha"'' by [[Vecheslav Zagonek]], ''"A Boat"'' by [[Elena Zhukova]], and some others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года. Каталог''. Л., Лениздат, 1951.</ref>
'''Still life paintings''' were presented of ''"Flowers"'' and ''"Still life"'' by [[Gleb Savinov]], ''"Still life"'' by Anna Kostina, and some others.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1951 года. Каталог''. Л., Лениздат, 1951.</ref>
== Acknowledgment == Exhibition was widely covered in press and in literature on Soviet fine art.<ref>''Художники народов СССР. Биобиблиографический словарь. Т. 1-4.''. М., Искусство, 1970-1995.</ref><ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.''- Saint Petersburg: NP-Print Edition, 2007. P.389.</ref><ref>''Галахов Н. Это Родина моя.'' СПб., Арт-Центр, 2009. С.14-15.</ref>
== See also ==

{{cleanup |reason=major gaps in the information.|date=July 2014}} {{unreferenced|date=June 2013}} '''Fine press''' [[printing]] and [[publishing]] comprises historical and contemporary printers and publishers publishing [[book]]s and other printed matter of exceptional intrinsic quality and artistic taste, including both commercial and [[private press]]es. Their dedication to fine printing distinguishes them from other [[small press]]es. Fine press publications are often published in [[limited edition]]s, that are swiftly bought up by [[Book collecting|book collectors]] and libraries.
==History of fine press==
As part of the [[Art Nouveau]] movement in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the Englishman [[William Morris]] wanted to hearken back to a golden age of printing, printmaking, and publishing. One of the books they published was the [[Kelmscott Chaucer]]. Soon, fine presses began to spring up in the United States as well. The most prominent was the [[Roycroft Press]]. Los Angeles was a center of the fine press movement, particularly centered on the Ward Ritchie press
==List of fine presses==
===United States=== * Alderbrink Press (1897 - 1928?) * Blue Sky Press (1899–1906) * Clerk's Press (1908–1919) * Cranbrook Press (1900–1902) * Elston Press (1900–1904) * Marion Press (1896–1931) * [[The Mosher Press]] (1891 - 1923+) Set up by [[Thomas Bird Mosher]] in 1891, in [[Portland, Maine]] * Philosopher Press (1896–1904) * [[Roycroft Press]] (1896 - 1915+) Set up by [[Elbert Hubbard]] in 1895 * [[Trovillion Press|Trovillion Press at the Sign of the Silver Horse]] Set up by Hal W. Trovillion in [[Herrin, Illinois]] in 1908 *[[John S. Fass|Hammer Creek Press]] (1950–1962) * [[Thornwillow Press]], New York (1985 - Present)
====California presses==== * [[Jane Bissell Grabhorn|Colt Press]], San Francisco * [[Grabhorn Institute|Grabhorn]] Press, San Francisco * John Henry Nash, San Francisco * Plantin Press, Los Angeles. Founded by Saul and Lillian Marks, in 1931 * Saunders Studio Press, Claremont. Founded by Lynne and Ruth Thompson Saunders in 1927 * Ward Ritchie Press * [[Arion Press]], San Francisco
===United Kingdom=== * [[Ashendene Press]] (1894–1935) * [[Daniel Press]] Oxford (1874–1903) * [[Doves Press]] (1900–1916) - Founded by [[T. J. Cobden-Sanderson]] and [[Emery Walker]] * Eragny Press (1894–1914) * Essex House Press (1898–1910) * [[Folio Society]] - Founded by [[Charles Ede]] in 1947 * [[Golden Cockerel Press]] - Founded by Harold Midgley Taylor in 1920 * Gregynog Press (1922-) - Founded by Gwendoline and Margaret Davies * [[Kelmscott Press]] (1891–1898) - Set up by [[William Morris]] in 1891 * [[Nonesuch Press]] - Founded in 1922 by Francis and Vera Meynell, and David Garnett * The Press of [[Gaetano Polidori]] * [[Strawberry Hill Press]] of [[Horace Walpole]] * Vale Press (1896–1905) * Vincent Press
===Continental Europe=== * [[Ad insigne pinus]] (1594–1619) In [[Augsburg]] * [[AIZ Dosije]] (1988-Present) In [[Belgrade]]
===Australia=== * [[Finlay Press]] founded and operated by [[Phil Day (artist)]] and Ingeborg Hansen in Australia. 1997-2009.

page.title: Global Recording Artist of the Year

revision.comment: /* Top 10 Global Recording Artists of the Year */ Fixed spelling of 'Global'
revision.text:
The '''Global Recording Artist of the Year''' is an award presented by the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]] (IFPI) to honor the most popular recording artist based on a total of [[album-equivalent unit]]s, which include [[music downloads]], [[streaming media|streaming]] and physical format sales.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.org/global-artist-chart.php|title=Global Artist Chart — IFPI — Representing the recording industry worldwide|website=www.ifpi.org|accessdate=4 December 2017}} It has been awarded every year since January 2014, with British boy band [[One Direction]] becoming the first act to receive the accolade for Global Recording Artist of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpi.org/news/One-Direction-are-officially-the-biggest-global-recording-artists-of-2013|title=One Direction are officially the biggest global recording artists of 2013|website=www.ifpi.org|accessdate=4 December 2017}} This success was attributed to the band's third studio album, ''[[Midnight Memories]]'', which became the best-selling album of the year with sales of four million copies worldwide.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2014/aug/01/one-direction-named-the-worlds-no-1-bestselling-artists|title=One Direction named the world's No 1 bestselling artists|first=Guardian|last=music|date=1 August 2014|publisher=|accessdate=4 December 2017|via=www.theguardian.com}} The music videos for its singles, "[[Best Song Ever]]" and "[[Story of My Life (One Direction song)|Story of My Life]]", had been watched almost 200 million and over 100 million times, respectively, on [[YouTube]] up to that point.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/earshot/one-direction-named-2013s-top-676027|title=One Direction Named 2013's Top Global Recording Artist|website=hollywoodreporter.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}} [[Taylor Swift]] was awarded the Global Recording Artist of 2014 after the commercial success of her fifth studio album, ''[[1989 (Taylor Swift album)|1989]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6480312/taylor-swift-named-ifpi-global-recording-artist-2014|title=Taylor Swift Named IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2014|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}} During the year, the album became the second global bestseller with sales of six million copies and spawned two international number-one singles, "[[Shake It Off]]" and "[[Blank Space]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-32315974|title=Digital music matches physical sales|date=15 April 2015|publisher=|accessdate=4 December 2017|via=www.bbc.com}} [[Adele]] received the award for the Global Recording Artist of 2015 with the release of her third studio album, ''[[25 (Adele album)|25]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6867321/adele-ifpi-global-recording-artist-2015|title=Adele Named IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2015|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}} It became the best-selling album of the year worldwide, selling 17.4 million copies. The album's lead single, "[[Hello (Adele song)|Hello]]" reached number one in nearly all countries where it charted, and became the seventh biggest digital song of the year with 12.3 million track-equivalent units.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-news/adeles-album-25-helped-reverse-two-decades-of-almost-uninterrupted-decline-in-music-industry-a3223361.html|title=Adele's 25 outsells the other top five bestsellers put together|website=standard.co.uk|accessdate=4 December 2017}} The Global Recording Artist of 2016 went to [[Drake (musician)|Drake]], whose fourth studio album, ''[[Views (album)|Views]]'', was the third best-selling album of the year with 2.3 million copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7685065/drake-ifpi-global-recording-artist-2016|title=Drake Named IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2016|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/7775037/ifpi-beyonce-lemonade-highest-selling-album-2016-drake-song|title=Beyonce's 'Lemonade' Highest-Selling Album Globally in 2016; Drake Lands Top Song: IFPI|website=billboard.com|accessdate=4 December 2017|date=25 April 2017}} ''View'' was more successful on streaming service, becoming the first album ever to accumulate one-billion streams on [[Apple Music]].{{cite news|last=Josephs|first=Brian|url=http://www.spin.com/2016/09/drakes-views-1-billion-apple-music/|title=Drake's Views Is The First Album To Earn 1 Billion Apple Music Streams {{!}} SPIN|date=2016-09-26|newspaper=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|accessdate=2016-10-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024023656/http://www.spin.com/2016/09/drakes-views-1-billion-apple-music/|archivedate=October 24, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The album's second single, "[[One Dance]]", which became the biggest digital song of the year, with 12.5 million track-equivalent units worldwide. [[Ed Sheeran]] received the award for the Global Recording Artist of 2017 with the release of his third studio album ''[[÷ (album)|÷]]'' (read as "divide") and its singles including "[[Shape of You]]", "[[Castle on the Hill]]", "[[Galway Girl (Ed Sheeran song)|Galway Girl]]" and "[[Perfect (Ed Sheeran song)|Perfect]]".{{cite news|title=Ed Sheeran officially named the best-selling global recording artist of 2017|url=http://www.ifpi.org/news/Ed-Sheeran-officially-named-the-best-selling-global-recording-artist-of-2017|accessdate=26 February 2018|agency=IFPI|date=26 February 2018}} He became the first IFPI Global Recording Artist of the Year to have both the best-selling album and single of the year. ==Top 10 Global Recording Artists of the Year== ===2013=== [[File:One Direction at the Logies Awards 2012.jpg|thumb|[[One Direction]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2013]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:70%" |- !Rank !Artist !IFPI Top 10 Album of the Year !IFPI Top 10 Single of the Year{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/music-sales-fail-to-go-in-one-direction-as-growth-turns-to-39-slide-9200304.html|title=Music sales fail to go in One Direction as growth turns to 3.9%|date=18 March 2014|website=independent.co.uk|accessdate=4 December 2017}} |- |1 !scope="row"|[[One Direction]] |''[[Midnight Memories]]'' (first) |{{n/a}} |- |2 !scope="row"|[[Eminem]] |''[[The Marshall Mathers LP2]]'' (second) |{{n/a}} |- |3 !scope="row"|[[Justin Timberlake]] |''[[The 20/20 Experience]]'' (third) |{{n/a}} |- |4 !scope="row"|[[Bruno Mars]] |''[[Unorthodox Jukebox]]'' (fourth) |"[[When I Was Your Man]]" (eighth) |- |5 !scope="row"|[[Katy Perry]] |''[[Prism (Katy Perry album)|Prism]]'' (sixth) |"[[Roar (song)|Roar]]" (fifth) |- |6 !scope="row"|[[Pink (singer)|Pink]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Just Give Me a Reason]]" (fourth) |- |7 !scope="row"|[[Macklemore & Ryan Lewis]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Thrift Shop]]" (second) |- |8 !scope="row"|[[Rihanna]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Stay (Rihanna song)|Stay]]" (tenth) |- |9 !scope="row"|[[Michael Bublé]] |''[[To Be Loved]]'' (seventh) |{{n/a}} |- |10 !scope="row"|[[Daft Punk]] |''[[Random Access Memories]]'' (fifth) |"[[Get Lucky (Daft Punk song)|Get Lucky]]" (sixth) |} ===2014=== [[File:Taylor Swift Red Tour 5, 2013.jpg|thumb|[[Taylor Swift]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2014]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:70%" |- !Rank !Artist !IFPI Top 10 Album of the Year !IFPI Top 10 Single of the Year |- |1 !scope="row"|[[Taylor Swift]] |''[[1989 (Taylor Swift album)|1989]]'' (second) |{{n/a}} |- |2 !scope="row"|[[One Direction]] |''[[Four (One Direction album)|Four]]'' (sixth) |{{n/a}} |- |3 !scope="row"|[[Ed Sheeran]] |''[[X (Ed Sheeran album)|X]]'' (third) |{{n/a}} |- |4 !scope="row"|[[Coldplay]] |''[[Ghost Stories (Coldplay album)|Ghost Stories]]'' (fourth) |{{n/a}} |- |5 !scope="row"|[[AC/DC]] |''[[Rock or Bust]]'' (seventh) |{{n/a}} |- |6 !scope="row"|[[Michael Jackson]] |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |- |7 !scope="row"|[[Pink Floyd]] |''[[The Endless River]]'' (ninth) |{{n/a}} |- |8 !scope="row"|[[Sam Smith (singer)|Sam Smith]] |''[[In The Lonely Hour]]'' (fifth) |{{n/a}} |- |9 !scope="row"|[[Katy Perry]] |{{n/a}} |"[[Dark Horse (Katy Perry song)|Dark Horse]]" (second) |- |10 !scope="row"|[[Beyoncé]] |{{n/a}} |{{n/a}} |- |} ===2015=== [[File:Adele 2016.jpg|thumb|[[Adele]] was awarded the IFPI Global Recording Artist of 2015]] {| class="wikitable unsortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; revision.comment: removed [[Category:LGBT art]]; added [[Category:LGBT arts organizations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''Great American Lesbian Art Show (GALAS)''' was an art exhibition at the [[Woman's Building]] (a feminist art center) in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] with associated events in other locations.<ref name=DIY-IK/><ref name=ArtInLA/> It ran from 3–31 May 1980.<ref name=DIY-IK/><ref name=Poster/><ref name=LATimes/> The Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Community Services Center also supported the exhibit.<ref name=Timeline/><ref name=IM-pg91/>
==Structure== The GALAS consisted of an "invitational" event, a curated exhibition of the work of ten selected artists, and many "regional" or "sister" exhibitions in multiple cities across the [[United States]].<ref name=DIY-IK/> These locations included New York City, [[San Francisco]], [[Boston]], [[Chicago]], [[Bozeman, Montana|Bozeman]], [[Winter Park, Florida|Winter Park]], [[Lawrence, Kansas|Lawrence]], [[Alexandria, Virginia|Alexandria]], and [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]] among "over 200 shows and events."<ref name=IM-pg91/><ref name=Art-of-Engage/><ref name=Reed-Art/> According to Margo Hobbs Thompson, the art displayed constituted "a critique of contemporary gender norms."<ref name=DIY-IK/> It was described by [[Terry Wolverton]], one of the organizers, as "a year-long project to bring national recognition to lesbian art and artists."<ref name=IM-pg91/> All of the invited artists lived in either Los Angeles or [[New York City|New York]].<ref name=IM-pg91/> GALAS was curated by the GALAS Collective including: Terry Wolverton, Bia Lowe, Jody Isanna Palmer, Tyaga, and Louise Moore. <ref name=Art-of-Engage/>
==Artists invited== The artists invited to participate in the curated exhibit were:<ref name=Poster/><ref name=IM-pg91/>
*[[Lula Mae Blocton]] *[[Tee Corinne]] *[[Betsy Damon]] *[[Louise Fishman]] *[[Nancy Fried]] *[[Harmony Hammond]] *Debbie Jones *[[Lili Lakich]] *[[Gloria Longval]] *[[Kate Millett]] (although she identifies as bisexual, not lesbian<ref name="glbtq.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/millett_k.html |title=>> literature >> Millett, Kate |publisher=glbtq |date= |accessdate=2013-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308211120/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/millett_k.html |archivedate=2014-03-08 |df= }}</ref>)
==Origins== Planning for the GALAS started in the spring of 1979. The organizing group, known as the GALAS Collective, was separate from the [[Lesbian Art Project]], which also met at the Woman's Building, although there was some overlap of membership.<ref name=DIY-IK/>
==Reactions== Tyaga, one of the event curators, was quoted by the [[Los Angeles Times]] while the exhibition was running as saying: "Just having the name 'Great American Lesbian Art Show' says a lot. It helps overcome fear. Art is non-threatening--it hangs on the wall and people look. It's the label that's the threat."<ref name=LATimes/>
[[Harmony Hammond]], writing in the ''Encyclopedia of Lesbian and Gay Histories and Cultures'' said that GALAS was "noteworthy for its innovative curatorial structure" and that it "marked the first time that lesbians of color participated in a major exhibition of lesbian art."<ref name=EoLaGHaC/>
Christopher Reed described GALAS as "poorly documented" but said that it showed "a greater interest in figuration among lesbian artists outside New York."<ref name=Reed-Art/>
Simon LeVay wrote about the art displayed at GALAS and another exhibition of roughly the same time: "For the first time a wide range of artists were willing to be public about being lesbians, although some of them still kept lesbian content as a suggestion rather than an overt statement in their art."<ref name=City-of-Friends/>
Sarah L. Stifler wrote of the "variety of media" in GALAS, but said that it did not include the "blatant references to sexuality" that were featured in the 1990 exhibition "All but the Obvious" (ABO).<ref name=Stifler-2002/> Stifler also wrote that "Much of my research has focused on" GALAS and ABO.<ref name=Stifler-2002/>
==Notes== {{reflist |refs= <ref name=DIY-IK>{{cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10894160903196558?journalCode=wjls20#preview|work=Journal of Lesbian Studies|title=DIY Identity Kit: The Great American Lesbian Art Show|doi=10.1080/10894160903196558|date=20 April 2010|pages=260–282|volume=14|first=Margo Hobbs |last=Thompson|subscription=yes|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=Timeline>{{cite web|url=http://womansbuilding.org/timeline.htm|title=Timeline|work=Woman's Building web site|accessdate=1 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111125014956/http://www.womansbuilding.org/timeline.htm|archivedate=25 November 2011|df=}}</ref> <ref name=ArtInLA>{{cite book|title=Live Art in LA: Performance in Southern California, 1970 - 1983|first=Peggy |last=Phelan|isbn=9781136467059|year=2012|publisher=Taylor & Francis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hSVl3jGtu3YC&pg=PT354&lpg=PT354&dq=The+Great+American+Lesbian+Art+Show&source=bl&ots=eyVt1UErpj&sig=ui4OhSZz6kMCVeMFJl00PB2JA_w&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZLztUtL5IqzMsQSGv4CwDA&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=The%20Great%20American%20Lesbian%20Art%20Show&f=false|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> <ref name=Poster>{{cite web|url=http://collections.otis.edu/u?/wb,546|title=Poster for "Great American Lesbian Art Show" |year=1979|first=Bia |last=Lowe|work=Woman's Building Slide Archive}}</ref> <ref name=LATimes>{{cite news|title=Art from Closet to Gallery|date=May 27, 1980|first=Diane|last=Elvenstar|pages=G1-G2|quote="Just having the name 'Great American Lesbian Art Show' says a lot. It helps overcome fear," says the exhibit curator with the single name, Tyaga. "Art is non-threatening--it hangs on the wall and people look. It's the label that's the threat."|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> <ref name=IM-pg91>{{cite book|title=Insurgent Muse: Life and Art at the Woman's Building|first=Terry |last=Wolverton|pages=91–2|isbn=0872864030|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nIZQqSOO5qUC&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90&dq=The+Great+American+Lesbian+Art+Show&source=bl&ots=vaU2YFuseP&sig=MZEZccfmDT_KTe1J-ukIx2ylPVM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cpXtUvv3JcqQyAGQnIGIDw&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=The%20Great%20American%20Lesbian%20Art%20Show&f=false|publisher=City Lights Publishers|year=2002}}</ref> <ref name=Art-of-Engage>{{cite book|title=Art of Engagement: Visual Politics in California and Beyond|editor-first=Susan |editor-last=Landauer|page=210|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=0520240529|year=2006|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nBIM6iKsaoEC&pg=PA218&lpg=PA218&dq=The+Great+American+Lesbian+Art+Show&source=bl&ots=vh38R0Mbg7&sig=OxRqtRUdpnoScKmpWWfCH5AyCf4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZLztUtL5IqzMsQSGv4CwDA&ved=0CC8Q6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=The%20Great%20American%20Lesbian%20Art%20Show&f=false|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> <ref name=EoLaGHaC>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Lesbian and Gay Histories and Cultures|chapter=Art, Contemporary North American|first=Harmony |last=Hammond|editor1-first=Bonnie |editor1-last=Zimmerman |editor2-first=George E. |editor2-last=Haggerty|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2000|pages=64–5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nvt8el4QtPwC&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64&dq=The+Great+American+Lesbian+Art+Show&source=bl&ots=m9z61DVoms&sig=OMqWROFdRkk5M-84izYMGplkt1E&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cpXtUvv3JcqQyAGQnIGIDw&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=The%20Great%20American%20Lesbian%20Art%20Show&f=false|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> <ref name=Reed-Art>{{cite book|first=Christopher|last=Reed|title=Art and Homosexuality: A History of Ideas|page=194|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2011|isbn=978-0195399073|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FXZAkTaNuHYC&pg=PA194&lpg=PA194&dq=The+Great+American+Lesbian+Art+Show&source=bl&ots=Rh91rzbV-M&sig=GVWiZ_ULoo7qj7KcN1lhPYnTEIE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZLztUtL5IqzMsQSGv4CwDA&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=The%20Great%20American%20Lesbian%20Art%20Show&f=false|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> <ref name=City-of-Friends>{{cite book|title=City of Friends: A Portrait of the Gay and Lesbian Community in America|first=Simon |last=LeVay|page=346|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=0262621134|year=1997|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cl-4yFFql8gC&pg=PA345&lpg=PA345&dq=The+Great+American+Lesbian+Art+Show&source=bl&ots=uOqwGR33iL&sig=63Wi7rzPUKR25oimYw6acuJ1BWc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ZLztUtL5IqzMsQSGv4CwDA&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=The%20Great%20American%20Lesbian%20Art%20Show&f=false|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> <ref name=Stifler-2002>{{cite journal|title=Slippery When Wet: An Exhibition Dossier|first=Sarah L. |last=Stifler|work=GLQ: A Journal of Lesbian and Gay Studies |volume=8|issue=1-2|year=2002|pages=241–249|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/glq/summary/v008/8.1stifler.html|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> }}

page.title: Henry IV at the Battle of Ivry

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Ivryrubens.jpg|thumb|280px]] '''''Henry IV at the Battle of Ivry''''' is a 1627 oil on canvas by the artist [[Peter Paul Rubens]], measuring 367 by 693 cm. It shows [[Henry IV of France]] at [[Battle of Ivry|Ivry]] and forms a pair with ''[[The Triumphal Entry of Henry IV into Paris]]'' - both were bought by [[Cosimo III de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Cosimo III de' Medici]] in 1686. They are both now in the [[Uffizi Gallery]] in Florence, where they have been since 1773.
==External links== *http://www.virtualuffizi.com/uffizi1/Uffizi_Pictures.asp?Contatore=436
{{Rubens}}
{{17C-painting-stub}} [[category:1627 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Peter Paul Rubens]] [[Category:Paintings of the Uffizi]] [[Category:War paintings]] [[Category:Horses in art]]

{{Infobox television episode | title = I'll Walk You Home | series = [[Holby City]] | series_no = 18 | episode = 35 | image = Arthur Digby death.png | caption = Arthur dies surrounded by his colleagues | airdate = {{Start date|2016|06|07|df=y}} | guests = *[[Jimmy Akingbola]] as [[Antoine Malick]] *[[Lauren Drummond]] as [[Chantelle Lane]] *Elizabeth Cadwallader as Alison Jones *Hayley Carmichael as Ines Maria *[[George Rainsford (actor)|George Rainsford]] as [[Ethan Hardy]] | writer = Andy Bayliss | director = Paulette Randall | photographer = Peter Butler | length = 58 minutes<ref name=episode/> | season_article = Holby City (series 18) | episode_list = List of Holby City episodes | prev = The Sky Is Falling | next = Missing You Already }} "'''I'll Walk You Home'''" is the thirty-fifth episode of the [[Holby City (series 18)|eighteenth series]] of the British [[medical drama]] television series ''[[Holby City]]''. The episode was written by Andy Bayliss and directed by Paulette Randall, and premiered on [[BBC One]] on 7 June 2016. The episode features the death of established character [[Arthur Digby]] ([[Rob Ostlere]]), a [[Modernising Medical Careers|CT2]] doctor who had worked on the show's fictitious Keller and AAU wards. Writers worked alongside a consultant oncologist for medical advice to provide an accurate depiction of terminal cancer. The episode also features the return of two former regular characters and includes an appearance of a character from ''Holby City's'' sister-show ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]''.
The episode was structured with positive and upbeat tones transitioning into the dark scenes focusing on death. "I'll Walk You Home" received positive reviews from critics for its "gritty" theme. All reviews noted that it was an emotional episode. Sarah Deen from the ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' branded it one of the "saddest episodes ever".
==Plot== Arthur and his wife [[Modernising Medical Careers|F1]] [[Morven Shreve|Morven Digby]] (Eleanor Fanyinka) announce their decision to go travelling. They want to spend the time Arthur has left visiting historic sites. His best friend [[Specialty registrar|CT1]] doctor [[Dominic Copeland]] ([[David Ames (actor)|David Ames]]) is upset and thinks that Arthur is being selfish. Consultant general surgeon [[Ric Griffin]] ([[Hugh Quarshie]]) tries to make Dom realise that it is Arthur's choice. He decides to distract himself by attending to patient Alison Jones (Elizabeth Cadwallader). Dom realises that he has been unfair to Arthur and they have a discussion. Dom hands Arthur war medals that were stolen from their flat months earlier. Arthur realises that he wants to stay in Holby City and live out his final days with friends.
Consultant cardiothoracic surgeon [[Jac Naylor]] ([[Rosie Marcel]]) sets [[Specialty registrar|CT1]] doctor [[Zosia March]] ([[Camilla Arfwedson]]) a series of surgical tasks to prove her worth. Zosia rises to the challenge but becomes tired of Jac's demands. Jac tells Zosia she is selfish and uncaring towards Arthur. She accuses her of giving Arthur a stent operation to advance her own career. Zosia confronts Jac and accuses her of being "cold", this does not phase Jac who ignores her. Zosia ex-boyfriend, [[Specialist registrar]] [[Oliver Valentine]] ([[James Anderson (English actor)|James Anderson]]) and [[Staff nurse]] [[Cara Martinez]] ([[Niamh Walsh]]) apologise to her for sharing a kiss. Cara gives Oliver a picture of his dead wife [[Tara Lo]] ([[Jing Lusi]]) and Zosia spots him with it. [[Staff nurse]] [[Essie Harrison]] ([[Kaye Wragg]]) rallies staff to get ready to perform a song and dance surprise for Arthur. They perform a dance routine and are joined by [[Ethan Hardy]] ([[George Rainsford (actor)|George Rainsford]]). [[Antoine Malick]] ([[Jimmy Akingbola]]) makes a video call to Arthur to wish him well.
Arthur goes to visit CEO [[Henrik Hanssen]] ([[Guy Henry (actor)|Guy Henry]]) and he tells him that he has finally realised what he wants from life. Arthur's stent bursts and he collapses on the floor. Hanssen calls a crash team and tries to comfort Arthur. [[Consultant (medicine)|Consultant]] [[Sacha Levy]] ([[Bob Barrett (actor)|Bob Barrett]]) and Ric try to operate on Arthur. Sacha announces that the cancer is too advanced and nothing more can be done and Ric agrees. Hanssen goes to AAU to inform Morven who is in theatre with [[Serena Campbell]] ([[Catherine Russell (actress)|Catherine Russell]]). Arthur is taken into a side room where Morven tells him that she loves him. Arthur is unconscious and has visions of Morven, Dom, Zosia and his old friend [[Chantelle Lane]] ([[Lauren Drummond]]). Arthur responds to Morven holding his hand but then dies surrounded by his friends and colleagues. Zosia breaks down on Darwin ward and Jac rushes to console her.
==Production== The episode focuses around the final scenes of Rob Ostlere as Arthur Digby following three years in the show. The actor had informed producers of his decision to leave six months prior. They then devised an exit storyline for the character in which he is diagnosed with terminal cancer. Ostlere was told of their intention to kill the character off, the results of which play out in "I'll Walk You Home".<ref name=woti/> The events of the episode could have been different as producer Simon Harper later gave Ostlere the chance to have his character leave the show alive.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kilkelly|first1=Daniel|title=Holby City producers reveal that Rob Ostlere could have saved his character Arthur Digby|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/holby-city/news/a796974/holby-city-rob-ostlere-arthur-digby-could-have-been-saved/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref>
The episode was produced by Jane Wallbank, written by Andy Bayliss and directed by Paulette Randall.<ref name=episode>{{cite web|title=I'll Walk You Home|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07f72gb|website=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> Storyliners had been liaising with a consultant oncologist named Bruce Sizer who gave advice on the medical condition featured in the episode.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arthur's last walk|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03xk5d1|website=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref> Writers structured the episode so it began "lovely and upbeat" until the closing scenes which contained Arthur's death.<ref name=woti/>
Former regular cast members Jimmy Akingbola and Lauren Drummond returned to filming especially for the episode, reprising their roles as Antoine Malick and Chantelle Lane respectively. Akingbola filmed scenes which were featured in a [[Skype]] video call. Drummond filmed scenes with other cast members, with her footage stylised as part of a dream sequence envisioned by Arthur.<ref name=woti/> The cast were involved in filming a number of dream sequences which were given a "surreal" feeling to them.<ref name=wotint>{{cite journal|title=Arthur's final journey|journal=[[What's on TV]]|date=4–10 June 2016|issue=22|pages=15|publisher=[[IPC Media]]}}</ref>
George Rainsford guest starred as Ethan Hardy, a character from ''Holby City's'' sister-show ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]''. His inclusion was a result of a decision made by executive producer Oliver Kent who oversees both shows. Rainsford and Ostlere had been asking Kent for the scenes for some time. The actors were friends for fourteen years and wanted their characters to share screen-time.<ref name=woti>{{cite web|title='It was a lovely, upbeat episode until Arthur's final moments!' Rob Ostlere reacts to his sudden Holby exit|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/holby-city/news/it-was-a-lovely-upbeat-episode-until-arthurs-final-moments-rob-ostlere-reacts-to-his-sudden-holby-exit|website=[[What's on TV]]|publisher=([[IPC Media]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref> After filming had wrapped for the episode Ostlere was supposed to give a farewell speech to the cast and crew but he was too upset.<ref name=departure/>
==Promotion== Producers wanted to keep exact details of the episode a secret until it was broadcast. They also wanted to Akingbola and Drummond's involvement quiet to surprise viewers.<ref name=insidesoap/> Though Ostlere did disclose that past characters would return in an interview published via ''[[What's on TV]]''.<ref name=wotint/> Advance spoilers only indicated that Arthur and Morven planned to leave ''Holby City'' to go travelling and that Zosia and Jac would feature in scenes on the show's Darwin ward.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Goodbye Arthur & Morven?|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|date=4–10 June 2016|issue=22|pages=27|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]}}</ref> The show released a promotional trailer for the episode a week in advance. It featured various characters and included parts of scenes that form Arthur's exit from the show.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trail: Next week on Holby City|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03wvd57|website=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> It was broadcast on 7 June 2016 on [[BBC One]] in the United Kingdom. A re-run was shown on [[BBC Two]] on 13 June 2016.<ref name=episode/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kilkelly|first1=Daniel|title=Holby City spoiler: 'I'll Walk You Home'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/holby-city/spoilers/a796147/holby-city-spoiler-morven-arthur-want-to-travel-the-world/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=1 June 2016}}</ref>
==Reception== The episode was watched by 4.4 million people during the BBC One airing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weekly top 30 programmes|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/viewing-data/weekly-top-30/|website=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]|accessdate=22 June 2016}}</ref> Arthur's death was nominated for "Best Drama Storyline" at the 2016 ''Inside Soap'' Awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/eastenders/news/a798505/inside-soap-awards-2016-longlist/|title=Inside Soap Awards 2016 longlist revealed: Which of your soap favourites are up for prizes?|last=Sandwell|first=Ian|date=21 June 2016|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref>
Laura Jayne-Tyler from ''[[Inside Soap]]'' said "Wow. That was one hell of an episode of Holby City." She added it was a struggle to recover from the "tear-jerking instalment" episode.<ref name=insidesoap>{{cite web|last1=Tyler|first1=Laura-Jayne|title=Spoilers! Holby City – what a shocker of an episode!|url=http://www.insidesoap.co.uk/spoilers-holby-city-what-a-shocker-of-an-episode/|website=[[Inside Soap]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref> Sara Wallis from the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' noted that hospital dramas can be emotional, but branded "I'll Walk You Home" a "particularly gritty and gruelling episode".<ref name=sarwilmirror>{{cite web|last1=Wallis|first1=Sara|title=Get your tissues at the ready for cancer-stricken Arthur Digby's Holby City exit tonight|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-previews/your-tissues-ready-cancer-stricken-8126606|website=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref> Another ''Daily Mirror'' critic warned viewers that it was "best to keep the hankies to hand" because the episode is emotional. They added the episode was full of surprises for Arthur.<ref>{{cite web|title=Goodbye Arthur. Best TV we love|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454272702.html|website=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=4 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref> Sarah Deen from the ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' said that his death "might be one of its saddest episodes ever". She called Arthur being readmitted to hospital "the most heartbreaking scenes". The scene involving Zosia and Jac breaking down in each other's arms "left viewers completely overcome with emotion". Deen concluded that "Holby really does pull at the heart strings when it’s ready."<ref name=finalscenes>{{cite web|last1=Deen|first1=Sarah|title=‘Bawling like a baby!’ Viewers get emotional over Holby City as cancer-stricken Arthur Digby dies|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/06/07/balling-like-a-baby-viewers-get-emotional-over-holby-city-as-cancer-stricken-arthur-digby-dies-5930204/|website=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|publisher=([[DMG Media]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref>
Kayleigh Dray from ''[[Closer (magazine)|Closer]]'' said the fact the episode featured the death of a "popular character" and made "tearjerking scenes". The critic noted that her colleagues were upset, adding "Oh Arthur, why did you have to ruin our makeup like that? We cried SO many tears for you."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dray|first1=Kayleigh|title=Holby City spoilers: Dr Arthur Digby’s funeral rocked by major disaster|url=http://lifestyle.one/closer/entertainment/soaps/holby-city-arthur-digby-cancer-dead-funeral-disaster/|website=[[Closer (magazine)|Closer]]|publisher=([[Bauer Media Group]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref> Frances Taylor from [[Bt.com]] said "fans of the BBC hospital drama were left weeping after the episode aired." She noted that the episode caused many viewers to discuss the show on social media website [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Taylor|first1=Frances|title=Holby City fans left distraught after Arthur Digby dies|url=http://tv.bt.com/tv/tv-soap/holby-city-fans-left-distraught-after-arthur-digby-dies-11364066699838|website=[[Bt.com]]|publisher=([[BT Group]])|accessdate=8 June 2016|date=8 June 2016}}</ref> Daniel Kilkelly from [[Digital Spy]] said it was a "heartbreaking episode". He chose the scenes in which Arthur was rushed to surgery as the most "tearjerking scenes".<ref name=departure>{{cite web|last1=Kilkelly|first1=Daniel|title=Holby City's Rob Ostlere reacts to Arthur Digby's emotional exit: 'It sparks a lot of change'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/holby-city/interviews/a796914/holby-citys-rob-ostlere-arthur-digby-exit/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref> The episode was included in a "TV Highlights" feature in ''[[TVTimes]]'' magazine and was given a three out of a possible four star rating.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Tuesday highlights|journal=[[TVTimes]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]|date=4–10 June 2016|volume=231|issue=23|pages=58}}</ref> The episode was included in ''[[Soaplife]]'' magazine's "must see TV" feature.<ref>{{cite journal|date=4–17 June 2016|title=Must see TV|journal=[[Soaplife]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]|issue=382|page=62}}</ref> The episode was also chosen for the "Pick of the day" features in the ''[[Coventry Telegraph]]'' and ''[[South Wales Echo]]''.<ref>{{cite web|first=Sara|last=Wallis|title=Doctor's in a Spin; Chats with Henrik Hanssen and Ric pick of the day Holby City BBC1, 8pm|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454308025.html|website=[[Coventry Telegraph]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Sara|last=Wallis|title=Doctor's in a Spin; pick of the day Holby City, 8pm|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454405039.html|website=[[South Wales Echo]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref> Due to the tough subject matter, a writer from the ''[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]'' branded it "Holby Gritty".<ref>{{cite web|title=TV record|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-454380688.html|website=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=([[Trinity Mirror]] via [[Highbeam Research]])|accessdate=9 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}{{subscriptionrequired}}</ref> Anthony D. Langford writing for ''[[TVSource Magazine]]'' said "Arthur’s death was very sad as I thought it would be. He was one of my faves on this show. I’ll miss him. I did mist up a few times during this episode, mostly during the song his co-workers sang to him. And Zosia’s reaction got me too."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvsourcemagazine.com/2016/06/gays-lives-padres-new-lover/2/|title=Gays of Our Lives: The Padre’s New Lover?|last=D. Langford|first=Anthony|date=13 June 2016|work=[[TVSource Magazine]]|publisher=(SoSource Media)|accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref>
